newsitem.title: UK: LONDON PRECIOUS METALS POP HIGHER, LED BY SILVER.
newsitem.headline: LONDON PRECIOUS METALS POP HIGHER, LED BY SILVER.

text.p: Silver raced higher on Friday afternoon, catching most of Europe short ahead of the long holiday weekend and giving a modest boost to the other precious metals.
A spate of physical and fund buying at silver's lows around $4.66 an ounce triggered technical "buy stops" around $4.72, traders said.
The white metal shot up to as high as $4.79, before coming off the boil. It was last trading somewhat off the highs at $4.75/$4.77, but still up seven cents from Thursday's London close.
"It looks like people were caught in a bear trap," one dealer said.
"Sentiment has been terrible with the PGMs (Platinum Group Metals) coming off this week, but people were also short gold and silver without the same fundamental backing," another added.
Last Friday silver prices had moved sharply in the opposite direction when speculative selling hit the market.
But over the past three days it had moved in a relatively tight range, holding above the $4.66 support level.
In the other precious metals markets, gold firmed slightly with silver and fixed at $342.55 an ounce, from $341.65 in the morning.
Dealers said they expected gold prices to mark time in a narrow band within the $340-$345 range for the rest of Friday.
"I think it's done for the day. With London and New York closed on Monday people are going to head home early today," a dealer said.
U.S. and U.K. markets will reopen on Tuesday.
Platinum and palladium were also off the day's lows after sharp tumbles in the Far East and early Europe, although sentiment was still bearish.
"Frankly they still look ghastly," a dealer said.
Palladium picked up off its nadir of around $167 and was last trading at $170.75/$171.75, down $4.00.

It had come under intense selling pressure in the Far East due to a weaker yen and news this week that long-delayed talks between Russian suppliers and Japanese consumers were due to start next month.
Platinum similarly was last at $388.00/$389.00, off $1.25. --Lida Poletz, London newsroom +44 171 542 2936
